newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian PM partly backs minister but says no coup.
newsitem.headline: Russian PM partly backs minister but says no coup.

text.p: Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin on Thursday gave partial support to his interior minister in bitter infighting against security chief Alexander Lebed, but he dismissed talk of "mutinies and putsches".

Chernomyrdin had summoned his top security staff to discuss allegations on Wednesday by Interior Minister Anatoly Kulikov that Lebed was planning to create a force of about 50,000 men to seize power while President Boris Yeltsin awaits heart surgery.
"I do not conceal my concern over the fact that a considerable part of what Minister Kulikov said corresponds with reality," Interfax news agency quoted Chernomyrdin as saying.
But he added: "(I am) far from thinking about mutinies and putsches".
Kulikov said on Wednesday that Lebed's plans amounted to a "creeping coup" while President Boris Yeltsin awaits a heart bypass operation planned for mid-November. Lebed denied the accusations.
Chernomyrdin, addressing a cabinet meeting which followed his talks with security officials, condemned the rivalries that have intensified ahead of Yeltsin's operation.
A presidential spokesman said on Tuesday that the president had called for an end to the squabbling.
"The irresponsibility and incompetence of home-grown Bonapartism is clearly over the top," Interfax quoted Chernomyrdin as saying on Thursday.
He said the situation was difficult in the armed forces, which are underfunded and demoralised, but added that he would not allow anyone to use this to their own ends.
Chermomyrdin confirmed on Thursday that an order had been given to step up security in "especially dangerous places" but he gave no details.
Kulikov said on Wednesday that he had ordered extra security measures to cope with what he said was a threat of attacks by rebels from the breakaway Chechnya region.
The minister had earlier said that about 1,500 Chechen rebels would support Lebed's planned new force. The rebels denied the charge.
